newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore sound makers in battle for PC market.
newsitem.headline: Singapore sound makers in battle for PC market.

text.p: Electronics-based Venture Manufacturing's new multimedia software will give Creative Technology's sound card business some competition, analysts said on Friday.
But they were divided over the extent of impact on the business of Creative, maker of the SoundBlaster card.
"There will be some impact," Siew Teng Kean, assistant manager at Ong Research said.
"The product could erode Creative's earnings by at least 10-20 percent in six to 12 months' time," said another analyst, who declined to be named.
On Friday, Venture Manufacturing launched NovaStation, a software that upgrades any SoundBlaster-16 or compatible 16-bit sound card to a high quality wavetable synthesizer.
Personal computer (PC) users will be able to hear 128 instruments simultaneusly from a choice of 676 instruments and 21 drum kits.
NovaStation is designed for Windows 95 and can be used on PCs based on Intel's MMX processors and older Pentium 100 MHZ systems.

The news sent Creative Technology's share price plummeting as much as S$1.90 (US$1.29) to S$34.60, after surging in the past week on expectations of strong earnings. Venture's share price rocketed to a high of Singapore $7.10, up S$1.95.
Creative recently launched its latest sound card, the AWE64 Value card, at US$99 each, targetted at replacing older 16-bit cards. The AWE64 can play 64 instruments simultaneously.
NovaStation, developed by Venture subsidiary Innovative Trek Technology Pte Ltd, will have a recommended retail price of US$49 when it zrrives in stores in two months' time.
Innovative general manager Christopher Ng said that as NovaStation was a software, PC users need not throw out their old soundcards.
Notebook computers will also be able to deliver realistic sounds with NovaStation, which they cannot now because they do hot have enough space to plug in a new sound card, he said.
Some analysts said Creative would face a limited threat from NovaStation at least in the first 12 months as the two companies' products were pitched at different markets.
Venture is targetting original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) which will bundle NovaStation with their products.
"Creative is targetting the retail market," David Toh, electronics analyst at ING-Baring said, adding that Creative also had a lot of clout with its brand name.
Analysts however conceded that NovaStation could take some of Creative's share from the OEM market.
But OEMs which produce top-of-the-line systems may still prefer Creative for its brand name, Siew added.
Ng said Innovative had already secured five OEM customers, the first of which will ship NovaStation with its CD-ROM drives next week.
The analyst who thought NovaStation would hit Creative's business quite hard said:
"It is a software product where Venture has the flexibility to move it down to a very low price. They can also sell it cheaply on the Internet which will attract the retail buyers."
Analysts said NovaStation would be a catalyst to Venture's share price moving as high as S$7-8.
